ceph-mon/templates/bin/moncheck/_reap-zo.message:
This doesn't work for whatever reason. I tried it in my lab. I thought it may be that piping is not supported, so I also tried the command below but it also didn't work for whatever reason.

mon_count_command='kubectl get daemonset ceph-mon --namespace=${NAMESPACE} -o jsonpath="{.status.desiredNumberScheduled}"'

I implemented this differently so the mon count is checked in the start script instead.

Previously reap-zombies.py was run every 30 seconds. Now it will only run if the mon count (from the Ceph cluster's perspective) has changed in the last 30 seconds. So mons will only be removed from the monmap if the count has changed in the last 30 seconds and the list in the monmap doesn't match the list of pods. In theory this means a new mon has to appear in the monmap in order to trigger a reap-zombies.py run.

ansible/roles/service-ks-register/tasks/.message:
This grants all roles with system scope, while it should be able to grant roles with project scope when a project is specified. Where roles should be granted with system scope, we'll need to update the relevant variables.

It is also granting everyone a role of {{ keystone_admin_user }}, which is admin. The role should be {{ item.role }}.
How could a role use keystone with the enforce scope enabled if it has a project scoped role?

Scope enforcement doesn't mean everything should use the system scope, it means everything should use the correct scope - system, domain or project. I'm not sure if any of the role we assign in Kolla should use project scope, but we do need to check.

There is also the question of whether we would assign roles both with system scope and project scope for some transition period, then remove the project-scoped role assignments. In that case this code would need to support both scopes.
Not done - it is still always granting roles with system scope. We will need to audit the users & roles to see if we need any project-scoped roles.

Add retries:

      register: service_ks_register_result
      until: service_ks_register_result is success
      retries: "{{ service_ks_register_retries }}"
      delay: "{{ service_ks_register_delay }}"

FYI, in cases of complex string values I have also had success in comparing version using LooseVersion in the comparator. I'll let author decide what to do.

from distutils.version import LooseVersion
if ((min_version is not None and LooseVersion(kube_version) < LooseVersion(min_version))
. . .

I was just concerned that in the case of >= 4.15 there might be problem with legacy code when isolcpus is not defined. I wanted to make sure we had no errors coming out. I'd prefer to retain our previous behaviour if we observe no issue when isolcpus is not defined.

Hello, I just noticed this code review. Jim, I have a question about the your comment.

The legacy code was as follows:

  
  if lowlatency:
    cpu_ranges.update({"nohz_full": rcu_nocbs_ranges})
  
  isolcpus_ranges = utils.format_range_set(vswitch_cpuset.union(app_isolated_cpuset))
  

You recommended changing the following:

  isolcpus_ranges = utils.format_range_set(vswitch_cpuset.union(app_isolated_cpuset))
  
  if lowlatency:
    cpu_ranges.update({"nohz_full": rcu_nocbs_ranges})
    kver_major_minor = tuple(int(ver) for ver in os.uname()[2].split('.')[0:2])
    if isolcpus_ranges and kver_major_minor >= (4, 15):
        cpu_ranges.update({"nohz_full": isolcpus_ranges})
  

to the following:


  isolcpus_ranges = utils.format_range_set(vswitch_cpuset.union(app_isolated_cpuset))
  
  if lowlatency:
    kver_major_minor = tuple(int(ver) for ver in os.uname()[2].split('.')[0:2])
  
    if kver_major_minor < (4, 15):
        cpu_ranges.update({"nohz_full": rcu_nocbs_ranges})
    elif isolcpu_ranges:
        cpu_ranges.update({"nohz_full": isolcpus_ranges})
  

However, as you noted, this will not set the nohz_full argument in the lowlatency and kernel version >= 4.15 case that does not have isolcpus set.

Legacy code always defined the nohz_full argument in lowlatency mode (regardless of whether isolcpus was in use), so that is why the change I proposed as an attachment in https://bugs.launchpad.net/starlingx/+bug/1925363 , which Mihnea has published, keeps that behaviour.

If we do not set nohz_full in lowlatency mode when isolcpus is not specified, then this is a change in behaviour.

For the record, I recall that all kernels work fine when nohz_full is specified without isolcpus. The only issue is when isolcpus and nohz_full are both defined but are not aligned (with kernels >= v4.15).

I just wanted to understand the your rationale for this suggestion.

Thanks!

swift/obj/reconstructor.py.message:
I wonder if it'd be better for us to just issue a HEAD to the last_part_node before doing anything. As is, we're still issuing a GET despite not being interested in the body, yeah?

I think it would avoid both the need to switch between wait-for-all/wait-for-quorum and the bucketing changes -- we can just go ahead and wait for the HEAD; on 2xx with a newer or equal timestamp we bail, anything else (including timeouts and socket errors) we try to rebuild.

And *then* it starts to feel like a pattern we could repeat for the replicator, at least when using ssync ;-)
What a great idea!! Good thinking.
Should we also be checking etags?

I'm a little worried about these -- we may find the frag index (0 through ndata+nparity-1) we want to rebuild, but not the actual *node* index... and I don't think that node index X will do the fast thing when it wants to sync with node index (X mod (ndata + nparity)). Indeed, now it may not end up syncing at all.

(If we keep this) I'm pretty sure we want `node` here, not `last_part_node`. Otherwise, I see logging like

 Found existing frag #1 at 127.0.0.1:6010/sdb5/9/AUTH_test/c/o policy#2 while rebuilding to 127.0.0.1:6010/sdb5/9/AUTH_test/c/o policy#2

which seems like some nonsense.

This feels weird -- bucket.is_useful() seems awkward for this, especially since we've only got the one response (so we don't expect the len() check to ever work out) and the only other way to get a True out *also* checks bucket.found_missing.

Really, I'm not sure that response buckets are a good way to think about this at all -- we're firing off a single request and looking for one of two things:

* the last primary is up and has the frag -- we should pass over this data file to give the last primary a chance to sync
* last primary doesn't have the frag, or is unavailable -- proceed with reconstruction

I think it'd be better to be more explicit about that here.
This definitely seems like a red flag indicating that buckets and _handle_fragment_response aren't the right way to think about this.

Seems weird that we pull a bucket-of-one out of _make_fragment_requests just so we can raise here -- why not increment the logger and raise closer to where we detect the last primary having data, like up around L587?

Makes sense, LGTM. As discussed on IRC, the tox_extra_args zuul variable can't be used to pass the exclude regex we need because the variable is also used when zuul runs tox without tests [1] and to show the tox config [2], and these steps will fail if we put the regex in tox_extra_args. There are also no other zuul variables that are appropriate for passing the regex [3].

So, we need to define a new env that uses the regex we need. It could either be in the nova repo or the placement repo, but I think it makes more sense to live in the nova repo as it involves running nova functional tests. Then we can reference it here in placement in order to run the functional tests here.

I feel like this is the 3rd time I've seen this bit of code in the chain, probably time to pull it out into ring.utils and reference it.
self.dev_id_bytes == 1 would imply new_none_dev_id = 0, so this is redundant. Maybe good belt & bracers, though?

wat?  isn't there properties for these values?

should we really be doing this in _gather_parts_from_failed_devices

Bah -- I'd meant to rewrite L1039 once I introduced the function:

 new_none_dev_id = none_dev_id(self.dev_id_bytes // 2)

The length check here is subtle, though -- an over-eager approach could see something like

* add 250 devices; stick with 8-bit dev_ids
* add 10 more devices; bump up to 16-bit dev_ids
* remove the last 5 devices; drop back to 8-bit dev_ids
* add 2 more devices; bump up to 16-bit dev_ids again

That seems like a lot of expanding and contracting for fairly minor changes, though, so instead I require that all devices fit into *N-1* bits to shrink down to N-bit dev_ids.

> should we really be doing this in _gather_parts_from_failed_devices

This is where we set self.devs[x] = None, so it seemed reasonable to also be the place to shorten self.devs. Once I was doing that, it seemed like a logical enough place to consider shrinking dev_id_bytes.

I don't like loosing the following behavior described in the docs:

"Updating the parameters in CephConfigOverrides and running a stack update will not change the running Ceph server."

One idea is to help preserve it is for this line to be a more generic variable which we can introduce into THT:

  tripleo_cephadm_apply_config_on_update

Then when deployed_ceph runs and produces an env file to pass during overcloud deployment we can have it automatically set that variable.

We can then update the documentation to add an "unless apply_config_on_update is true" and "we recommend you set it false after deploying the overcloud with deployed_ceph".
since we have the above proposed changes I consider this issue resolved unless any comments otherwise.

As discussed on the call today we aren't going to go ahead with this change of the in-code default in Nova until Yoga so in the short term we will need TripleO/THT/puppet-nova to default the mkisofs_cmd [1] configurable to mkisofs (currently genisoimage) when using el9.

yes we need the puppet-nova change. that's not what I wanted to say. But we could set mkisofs as the default in puppet-nova if other distributions also set a link for mkisofs to genisoimage for the current genisoimage package, makes sense?
Ah cool, if xorriso does the same between /usr/bin/genisoimage and /etc/alternatives/mkisofs then we can just switch the package for now without puppet-nova or THT changes.
xorriso seems to be available from rhel-8-for-x86_64-appstream-rpms

> in el8 with genisoimage, mkisofs is a link to genisoimage, so mkisofs is availability with either package and could be used as the default in puppet-nova if other distributions do the same?
> 
> # ll /usr/bin/mkisofs
> lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root 25 Dec 11  2020 /usr/bin/mkisofs -> /etc/alternatives/mkisofs
> # ll /etc/alternatives/mkisofs
> lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root 20 Dec 11  2020 /etc/alternatives/mkisofs -> /usr/bin/genisoimage

so we should keep genisoimage package then, to keep that link around and to no break c8 based backports

It doesn't AFAICT so my -1 here still applies, I think we need to..

- Add xorriso to the containers alongside genisoimage 
- Update puppet-nova and THT to switch the mkisofs_cmd configurable over to mkisofs (dependent on the above change)
- Remove genisoimage from the container (dependent on the above change)
- Backport the above series back to stable/wallaby

Thoughts?

> so we should keep genisoimage package then, to keep that link around and to no break c8 based backports

I'm not sure we can keep genisoimage package in TCIB as it will fail to build the containers in el9:

> run: dnf -y install {{ tcib_packages['common'] | join(' ') }} && dnf clean all && rm -rf /var/cache/dnf

I believe that we should just leave xorriso in the containers since it's available in both el8 and el9, and maybe have puppet-nova either install or remove genisoimage/xorriso depending on major release and define mkisofs_cmd based on that as well?

In Ubuntu, mkisofs is not part of alternatives, but symlinks directly to genisoimages, as opposed to CentOS that goes through alternatives, so we need to keep that in mind if we symlink.

If the dependent change goes through, we don't need to change mkisofs_cmd in tht as it will work by default on all distros.

Let me know if I'm missing something.
Sorry my understanding is that W, X and Y are going to be under C9/RHEL9, so that would be necessary on all these branches. Let's sync up later about this.

os_brick/initiator/connectors/iscsi.py.message:
This is the only file in os_brick that puts the exception in parentheses.  Not sure why, they don't do anything, but might as well be consistent, I guess.

The real question I wanted to ask, though, is I guess your experiments have shown that the default retries=3 works fine for this fix?

I have tested using PureStorage backend and saw that all the iscsiadm -m node -T <target> -p <portal> were sent out and got the return code of 21 in about 0.01s. And then all the iscsiadm -m node -T <target> -p <portal> --interface default --op new sent out at about the same time and got the return code of 0 or 6 back in about 0.02s. After 2 second sleep, the failed one(s) retried and passed.

The database error reported in the bug is "Could not make /etc/iscsi/nodes/iqn.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx: File exists" which seems like yet another race condition within Open iSCSI when there are concurrent requests from os-brick, and the concurrent requests happen because os-brick has a race condition between L1067 and L1070 with another os-brick thread.

So in my opinion a nicer solution would be to use an in-process lock using the target and portal as the lock name, because it would reduce the load on the system (fewer iscsiadm calls that can fail) and doesn't have the issue that the retry does, where it can reach the retry limit with high concurrency.

Gorka, Thanks for your comments and understood your concerns. Based on the logs, it seems that the database error is introduced by the database access of all the threads, not the same thread for a target plus portal - I only have one lun in that testing. To add a lock, do you think I can just lock the _connect_to_iscsi_portal method for all access, instead of target and portal? Please advise. If you agree, I'll go ahead add the lock

Gorka, thanks for providing the comments. Currently the lock is on connect_volume. In case of multipath, multi-threads are created before invoking _connect_vol. Based on the logs, it seems that somehow the database error is caused by the interaction of all the threads. Do you think we can add another lock at the _connect_vol? Or shall we just use the retry mechanism for now? Please refer to below log and please let me know. Thanks!

2021-09-22 21:53:32.747 172209 DEBUG oslo_concurrency.processutils [-] Running cmd (subprocess): iscsiadm -m node -T iqn.2010-06.com.purestorage:flasharray.3d75f52157933f4e -p 172.31.0.252:3260 --interface default --op new execute /var/lib/openstack/lib/python3.6/site-packages/oslo_concurrency/processutils.py:379
2021-09-22 21:53:32.762 172209 DEBUG oslo_concurrency.processutils [-] CMD "iscsiadm -m node -T iqn.2010-06.com.purestorage:flasharray.3d75f52157933f4e -p 172.31.0.248:3260 --interface default --op new" returned: 0 in 0.023s execute /var/lib/openstack/lib/python3.6/site-packages/oslo_concurrency/processutils.py:416
2021-09-22 21:53:32.762 172209 DEBUG oslo_concurrency.processutils [-] CMD "iscsiadm -m node -T iqn.2010-06.com.purestorage:flasharray.3d75f52157933f4e -p 172.31.0.247:3260 --interface default --op new" returned: 6 in 0.028s execute /var/lib/openstack/lib/python3.6/site-packages/oslo_concurrency/processutils.py:416
2021-09-22 21:53:32.762 172209 DEBUG oslo.privsep.daemon [-] privsep: reply[140222308533816]: (4, ('', 'iscsiadm: Could not make /etc/iscsi/nodes/iqn.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx: File exists\niscsiadm: Error while adding record: encountered iSCSI database failure\n')) _call_back /var/lib/openstack/lib/python3.6/site-packages/oslo_privsep/daemon.py:511
2021-09-22 21:53:32.762 172209 DEBUG oslo_concurrency.processutils [-] CMD "iscsiadm -m node -T iqn.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx -p 172.31.0.251:3260 --interface default --op new" returned: 0 in 0.023s execute /var/lib/openstack/lib/python3.6/site-packages/oslo_concurrency/processutils.py:416
2021-09-22 21:53:32.763 172209 DEBUG oslo.privsep.daemon [-] privsep: reply[140222308534120]: (4, ('New iSCSI node [tcp:[hw=,ip=,net_if=,iscsi_if=default] 172.31.0.251,3260,-1 iqn.2010-06.com.purestorage:flasharray.3d75f52157933f4e] added\n', '')) _call_back /var/lib/openstack/lib/python3.6/site-packages/oslo_privsep/daemon.py:511
2021-09-22 21:53:32.763 171181 DEBUG os_brick.initiator.connectors.iscsi [req-ce76511c-924a-4a57-883c-539cd0d7b27d - - - - -] iscsiadm ('--interface', 'default', '--op', 'new'): stdout= stderr=iscsiadm: Could not make /etc/iscsi/nodes/iqn.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx: File exists
iscsiadm: Error while adding record: encountered iSCSI database failure

Your analysis is correct, the issue is on multipathing and it would only happen on arrays that share the target and portal (only LUN changes between different volumes).

So we could add a lock using the target and portal to prevent multiple _connect_to_iscsi_portal so it only blocks the cases that can fail.  And since there is no limit we wouldn't have the problem the retry has.

Also, we could have similar Open iSCSI DB problems on all thee _iscsiadm_update commands in this method and on the login (L1116), so a locking would prevent any errors there as well, whereas with retry we have to go one by one making sure that we raise the right exception for the retry.
-1: Please move it to debug level
-1: It seems weird to raise this exception, since we are not searching for the device.  We can use the generic BrickException instead
I believe we should use a lock using the target and portal instead, for the reasons explained on Patchset #6

os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py.message: This is unrelated to the actual bugfix right? It looks like this is doing the correct thing regardless but you might want to throw it in a follow up change.

So is it guaranteed that there will only be a single path in the response, possibly with some whitespace at the end?  Was that paths.split()[0] on line 215 in the base patch just a misleading way to do an rstrip?

yes, that split()[0] was to get rid of '\n', and the paths should be path. We can only have one Linux link to point to one file. For example:

>>> subprocess.run(['readlink', '-e', '/dev/disk/by-id/nvme-eui.0d7b617d3e15c8978ccf09680015bdf4'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE).stdout
b'/dev/nvme0n1\n'
>>> b'/dev/nvme0n1\n'.rstrip()
b'/dev/nvme0n1'
>>> b'/dev/nvme0n1\n'.split()[0]
b'/dev/nvme0n1'

rstrip makes clear we don't have a list of paths.

eui.0d7b617d3e15c8978ccf09680015bdf4 is unique identifier of a disk
With this change, both _get_device_path_by_nguid() and _get_device_path() return a single path as a string data type, so nova will find what it expects in the device_info.

This isn't defined outside of the role so it can easily be overridden if required.
why are we doing the role_ prefix? it looks odd
Agreed that mariadb_port wasn't the best example. Credentials are a good one.

Take `mariadb_port` for example. It might be overridden in globals.yml which is included with -e when Kolla Ansible runs. If it is then it will take precedence over all other places in which it is set. But what if you want to use different MariaDB ports for different groups of hosts, because you want multiple instances of MariaDB? By abstracting `mariadb_port` it's easy to maintain backwards compatibility, but also support flexibly overriding the port. For example, this patch supports defining multiple MariaDB clusters via inventory group vars.

I used the role_ prefix here because something similar was done in the RabbitMQ role which also supports deploying multiple instances of RabbitMQ. I know it looks weird, but mariadb_mariadb_port seemed even weirder.

Just to be clear, host variables work fine with mariadb_port. The reason why we would want a separate role variable is if we have multiple instances of mariadb on a single host, or different types of databases for which we'd like a different top-level variable to configure.

It was done for RabbitMQ to support the inner and outer rabbitmq instances that can run on the same host.

In this case, I don't think we'd want to run multiple mariadb instances on a host. Where this use of role variables might be useful is if we want a separate cells DB instance, and want a separate variable to configure the username/password, e.g.

- import_role:
    role: mariadb
  vars:
    role_mariadb_username: mariadb_username

- import_role:
    role: mariadb
  vars:
    role_mariadb_username: cells_mariadb_username

ansible/roles/mariadb/tasks/check.yml.message: What's the reasoning behind adding this task? To make sure we're checking all instances? We do have some checks in the handlers, but don't actually execute any SQL.
It was indeed to check all instances, or a single instance not via the VIP if HAProxy isn't in use. I've switched to using the original task for all cases, and will rely on the existing checks.
This should be database_port as it's the frontend.
That is true. I guess it doesn't work with our haproxy then. Maybe we should fix that. It could feasibly work with an external load balancer though.

In the existing setup, database_port is the port that haproxy listens on, and the port generally used to access the DB. mariadb_port is the port that mariadb listens on. Without haproxy these must be the same, but could feasibly be different with haproxy.

So we need role_mariadb_database_port and role_mariadb_port in the new world, for the frontend and backend.

I'm not sure that I follow. Surely this task (and others) need to connect to the DB on the port that it is listening on? If HAProxy is in use, the port exposed on the VIP is locked to that same port. I am thinking of multiple DBs, where they may be mapped to specific services, and they may need to listen on different ports.

It seems that for each service that supports being deployed with a dedicated DB, we need to abstract `database_port` to role_<service>_database_port or whatever to allow it to be customised?

I see that the haproxy role checks that database_port is free, but in roles/mariadb/defaults/main.yml the haproxy stanza uses `mariadb_port` so surely it all locked to one port or are you suggesting that someone might override mariadb_services?
we have behavior change in here
I must have been tired writing that comment. I cannot remember what I meant there exactly. It seems fine as you say.
It's essentially the same, since role_mariadb_database_address is set to database_address and role_mariadb_database_port to database_port.
why not run_once and delegate_to instead? (like in other places)
This change was made to support deploying multiple instances in parallel (the groups could be set via inventory host vars for example).

ansible/roles/mariadb/tasks/lookup_clust.message:
It works as-is without re-including the role.

Example inventory could be:

[mariadb:children]
main-mariadb
cell0001-mariadb
cell0002-mariadb
                  
[main-mariadb]    
control01

[cell0001-mariadb]
control02

[cell0002-mariadb]
control03

Then in group vars:

[vagrant@operator group_vars]$ cat cell0001
cell_mariadb_namespace: cell0001
cell_mariadb_group_name: cell0001-mariadb
cell_mariadb_port: 1235

[vagrant@operator group_vars]$ cat cell0002
cell_mariadb_namespace: cell0002
cell_mariadb_group_name: cell0002-mariadb
cell_mariadb_port: 1236


If you run that, this patch will deploy the regular top level MariaDB instance, and two other ones all the same time.

Disadvantages are the extra skips tasks and the risk of taking out multiple databases all at the same time if you don't limit the run to a single group of whatever. We could run it in serial mode and then go back to run_once.

This is so the role can run in parallel to bring up multiple, independent clusters configured via group_vars at the same time. When using run_once it will only run the task on one cluster. Whether we use it this way for cells is another question - I know that you prefer the serial approach because it's more difficult to nuke all the DBs at the same time. This works for both approaches, but does have the minor downside of printing the skipped task as you point out.
I dug this one up - I don't agree. You have to reinclude the role for each host group anyway - then run_once will be run once again.

environments/enable-secure-rbac.yaml.message:
We definitely need to revert this change, and retain the other value.
- cinder uses "is_admin:True" internally in places where it creates an elevated version of the user's context.
- The "and is_admin_project:True" portion is necessary in order to ensure it's a system admin, and *not* a project admin. In cinder, project admins have very little additional authority over project members, so when cinder refers to an admin_api it's only for use by system admins.

Thanks for the clarification on the is_admin bit.

Is the second part of the check necessary though? The default value for is_admin_project in oslo.context is True [0] and it's deprecated [1]. That said, is it really just a role:admin check?

[0] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.context/blob/master/oslo_context/context.py#L213
[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.context/blob/master/oslo_context/context.py#L326

Also, this change isn't changing the behavior of is_admin at all, since that's handled by cinder's context object [0]. Is the idea that we should keep rule:admin_api consistent with the is_admin:True check because cinder internals rely on context.is_admin?

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/context.py#L134-L139

I take your point about 'is_admin_project' being deprecated, and cinder seems to acknowledge the fact [1]. But [1] states, "these legacy rules are still used in Xena" and so I assume they should be retained here. All of cinder's Xena tests were based on [1], and changing the admin_api rule here seems risky.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/803748/9/cinder/policies/base.py#156

I definitely agree with removing the "xena_" prefix from the rule names, but suggest we retain the "system_" portion. As I noted in my comment at L1970, when cinder refers to an "admin" we generally mean a system admin. That's because project admins generally don't have much more capabilities than project members.

tl;dr, recommend these be "systen_admin_or_project_member" and "system_admin_or_project_reader"
Done
I think these are replaced by L1971..L1976, and so L1977..L1982 should be deleted.
Done

This policy is deprecated in Xena, so I wonder if it should not be included in a policy override file. The new policies are listed at L2112, L2118 and L2121.

Of course, should backport this to Wallaby then the 3 new policies would need to be removed, and the legacy policy at L2115 restored.

Good call, does cinder use the granular checks? Or does it reference the group:group_types_manage policy in Xena? Which ever policy is being called from cinder's code, is the one that I think we should include here.

Same thing here. "group:access_group_types_specs" is the Wallaby policy that is replaced in Xena by separate "get" L2127, "get_all" L2133, "create" L2136, "update" L2139 and "delete" L2142 policies.

So I think this one at L2124 can be deleted, but we'll need to add it back if backported to Wallaby.

ansible/roles/kolla-openstack/tasks/conf.message: For patterns other than '*', this filters out any files that don't match, including directories.
Are you suggesting we should try to incorporate the excludes part into patterns?
I'm interested to know how kayobe custom config could end up with these in.

When kolla_extra_config_path does not have the value set (the default), https://opendev.org/openstack/kayobe/src/branch/master/ansible/roles/kolla-openstack/vars/main.yml#L102 becomes /. This is the why the molecule tests were timing out. 
The workarounds in this patch are tailored towards that specific case, although there is a possibility of symlinking any of the extra config directories to / (or /sys, or /proc), or creating loops somewhere else.
I wonder if given the upcoming re-write of the extra config feature, setting default value in https://opendev.org/openstack/kayobe/src/branch/master/ansible/roles/kolla-openstack/defaults/main.yml#L3 for now would be a sufficient workaround (although hitting the loop would be still a possibility)?
Why follow here but not for the find?

The lack of follow in the find is to avoid getting into the loops. The follow in the stat call allows us to determine the type (isdir, isreg) that is then used in filtering down the line. Without it only islnk will be set to true.
Would this work for doubly symlinked files?

Assuming that you referring to symlinks pointing at symlinks, then yes it should. Given the links pointing outside the environments/osdevlocal/kolla/config/cinder directory:

 ├── ceph.conf -> ../../../../../kolla/config/ceph.conf.link
 ├── cinder-backup -> ../../../../../kolla/config/cinder-backup-link
 ├── cinder-backup.conf
 ├── cinder-volume
 │   └── ceph.client.cinder.keyring
 └── cinder-volume.conf -> ../../../../../kolla/config/cinder/cinder-volume.conf

where

 ls -la ../../../../../kolla/config/cinder-backup-link
 lrwxrwxrwx. 1 vagrant vagrant 20 Oct  7 15:02 ../../../../../kolla/config/cinder-backup-link - 
 > cinder/cinder-backup
 ls -la ../../../../../kolla/config/ceph.conf.link
 lrwxrwxrwx. 1 vagrant vagrant 16 Oct  7 14:57 ../../../../../kolla/config/ceph.conf.link -> 
 cinder/ceph.conf

kolla/config/cinder becomes

 ├── ceph.conf
 ├── cinder-backup
 │   ├── ceph.client.cinder-backup.keyring
 │   └── ceph.client.cinder.keyring
 ├── cinder-backup.conf
 ├── cinder-volume
 │   └── ceph.client.cinder.keyring
 └── cinder-volume.conf
It would be a bit more efficient to use the together lookup: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/together_lookup.html

build-tools/stx/build-pkgs.message:
The way this function is used, it appears you are looking for a list of packages to build.
The lst files in this directory are for binary package that we can use without building, eith er in the final product and/or to satisfy the build dependencies of thos package that we do build.

Finding packages to build is done by discovery, scanning the pkg_dir_file at the root of any git repos found.
Yes, all buildable packages will be fetched by scanning 'debian_pkg_dirs' in each source layer in "cgcs-root/stx/[integ|kernel|*]". This will be corrected in the next version of review.

Hard coded for 'std' build.  What about 'rt', or other build types?
I think this function also needs to accept a build_type argument.
Yes, ^_^  hope to understand that originally we just want to setup the build system ASAP, but now it's time to correct all these hardcode things. This will be updated in new version review.

These are not layers, but rather repos.
Not all repos reside in the stx subdirectory.  
A method for the discovery of repos is required.

The function 'fetch_debian_folder' is used to find the package's 'debian' meta folder, for example:  for package 'ntp', at first, 'cgcs-root/stx/integ/debian_pkg_dirs" is found and read, 
then ‘base/ntp’ is appended to 'cgcs-root/stx/integ/', then we found the debian folder path:
'cgsc-root/integ/base/ntp/debian/[devvers|meta_data.yaml]'.

Could you please give example on "These are not layers, but rather repos.
Not all repos reside in the stx subdirectory."?  The function 'fetch_debian_folder' is called to generate the debian dsc file with the found debian meta.
Thanks
